awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Sustainable Solutions for Li-ion Batteries through Cycle-Life Improvements in Nanostructured, 'Green' Cathodes
awd_abstract_narration:
PI Name: Subramanian, Arunkumar
Proposal ID: 1453966

Electric vehicles are one alternative for reducing fossil fuel consumption and greenhouse gas production for sustainable transportation needs.  Electric vehicles require rechargeable batteries that balance the electrical energy storage and power delivery needs, and these batteries must have a life span sufficient to reduce cost and achieve true carbon footprint reduction.  Furthermore, batteries should be manufactured from sustainable materials to minimize environmental impact.  Towards these ends, this research seeks to advance the sustainability of lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery technology through life-span improvements of electrodes made from sustainable materials based on lithium-manganese oxide mixtures.  A unique aspect of the research plan is to study battery materials made from single "nanowires" to better understand the fundamental processes that reduce lithium-ion battery lifespan. If successful, this research will advance energy storage technology for future clean energy needs, particularly in the transportation sector. The education and outreach programs associated with this award will extend the impact of the research outcomes into the broader, STEM educational ecosystem in the Richmond, Virginia region.  Educational activities include K-12 outreach programs delivered through the ?NanoFellows Institute and Summer Regional Governor's School initiatives at the Math Science Innovation Center (MSiC), and through the Richmond Area Program for Minorities in Engineering (RAPME). These initiatives will introduce students to exciting opportunities that exist for delivering societal impact as future scientists and engineers to the area of sustainable energy.

The overall technical goal of this CAREER award is to gain a fundamental understanding of intrinsic storage capacity in Li-ion batteries through a focused analysis on single intercalation nanowire cathodes made from sustainable lithium/manganese oxide composites. Towards this end, the first research objective is to measure the lithium storage capacity of a single alpha-phase manganese dioxide (MnO2) nanowire cathode with a resolution better than 0.03 Li atoms per host molecule.  Single MnO2 nanowires will be subjected to different electrochemical cycling depths in order to reveal the correlation between crystal changes and capacity retention.  The second objective test the hypothesis that the intrinsic capacity fading in these intercalation cathodes will be improved by minimizing the structural and electronic conductivity changes, which occur within their host crystal during reversible ionic intercalation.  This will be achieved by the use of controlled lithia-doping and further ammonia treatment to stabilize the 2x2 tunnel structure of the host crystal through alleviation of Jahn-Teller distortions.  Experimentally, lithium/manganese dioxide nanowire cells will be integrated with nanoelectromechanical resonators to quantify the lithium capacity of the nanowire through its electrochemically-induced mass changes.  Four electrochemically-correlated measurements will be performed on this single nanowire at specific charge-discharge cycle numbers that are spread over its cycle-life: (1) TEM imaging to characterize the microstructure, (2) electronic conductivity measurements, (3) contact-mode AFM to study nanomechanical softening, and (4) charge capacity measurement using in-situ electron microscopy-based dynamic resonance measurements. Since capacity fading with progressive cycling is a key failure mode that is common to diverse electrode material systems as well as to different ionic intercalation systems, the new scientific knowledge and other advanced experimental capabilities, which will emerge from this effort, have the potential to go beyond the lithium-MnO2 system and to transform the electrode design strategies for future electrochemical energy storage systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Due to its favorable energy density and high output voltage, lithium-ion (Li-ion) technology is a key component of energy storage solutions in diverse industries ranging from consumer electronics and implantable devices to transportation. However, if Li-ion batteries are to also emerge as a sustainable energy technology of the future, new strategies are essential to further increase their life-span and to advance carbon-related benefits through the use of ‘green’ components in batteries. This CAREER project explored solutions to meet these goals through: (1) delivery of new atomic-to-nanoscale characterization methodologies and the knowledge that emerged from their use to study the stabilization of battery cathode materials, which is a key component that impacts battery life-span, and (2) the use of these capabilities to study materials containing Manganese, which is ‘green’ or non-toxic and abundant, as opposed to Cobalt that is more commonly used in cathodes. An important aspect of these materials is their use in the nanowire geometry, which are cylindrical elements with ultra-small diameters of less than 50 nanometers (a thousandth in fraction of the diameter of human hair) and lengths, which are typically 2 orders of magnitude larger than their diameters. Furthermore, these manganese dioxide nano-cylinders contain an array of “tunnels” or porous channels, which serve as pathways for the placement and transport of charge carrying ions during their insertion and extraction processes. Emphasis in this project was placed, in substantial part, on material testing platforms and capabilities that study performance at the single-particle level and in true battery-like, flooded-electrolyte configurations with commercial carbonate-based electrolytes. This strategy aided in the testing of a battery material near its intrinsic performance limits through the elimination of electrode tortuosity and associated inter-particle transport impedances, and is anticipated to be a key outcome of this NSF CAREER project. Another important area of emphasis related to comprehensive computational modeling of the charge storage mechanisms in manganese dioxide nanowires with a view towards understanding and optimizing their performance in lithium-ion batteries.

During the tenure of this project, these research activities involving a synergistic combination of experiments and simulations delivered several important contributions. First, considerable new knowledge has been gathered on diverse aspects of manganese dioxide cathodes. This includes charge storage capacity, lithium diffusion kinetics, microstructural transformation upon charge insertion / transport, degradation mechanisms, the role of surface facets and defects, and crystal stabilization through the introduction of ionic species. Next, electron transport performance was studied to complement and understand the rate performance observed in bulk-scale manganese dioxide electrodes. Another area of emphasis involved studies centered on understanding the mechanical properties of these nanoceramic materials through the use of scanning probe microscopy techniques. These experiments and simulations revealed performance regimes involving recoverable plasticity that offer avenues for mechanical stabilization of these materials. The transmission electron microscopy capabilities developed within this CAREER project were also deployed to perform microstructural imaging, elemental mapping, spectroscopy, and chemical composition characterization of the electrode reaction products formed in lithium-air batteries. These next-generation electrochemical systems possessed a long cycle life as well as delivered favorable charge storage at high rates, and point to the impact of this project on material characterization in electrochemical systems that go beyond Li-ion technology. This project also yielded an invention for controlled transport of matter at the atomic-to-nanoscale. The invention, which is the subject of a pending patent application, emerged from the chip nanofabrication process employed within this project to create on-chip nanoelectrochemical cells and helped achieve the smallest nozzles realized to-date on silicon chips (sized as small as 20 nanometers in lateral dimensions). This activity represents an important broader impact of the project towards applications that extend beyond battery electrochemistry and has the potential to impact technological applications such as few-nanometer structuring, nanolithography, spray coating, flexible electronics, and drug discovery.

In the end, this project resulted in new understanding that advances the science and engineering of lithium and beyond-lithium batteries, developed new characterization technology, and delivered new insights to stabilize as well as improve the performance of battery materials. The project resulted in multiple journal publications and a pending patent application, and trained graduate students in interdisciplinary skills involving battery electrochemistry, electron microscopy and spectroscopy, scanning probe microscopy based material testing, directed assembly of nanomaterials, chip-based nanofabrication, and multi-scale computational techniques / tools.


Last Modified: 01/14/2022
Modified by: Arunkumar Subramanian
